subject: Re: [junit] use of setUp and tearDown
msgSnippet: ... Sure, but why do you want the code that parses / transforms xml to objects and the code that works with these objects *in one test*? Why don t you have two
messageBody:
On Thursday 26 May 2005 23:48, Cedric Beust wrote:
> > If you don't want to test the XML to object mapping, then why
> > bother with XML at all in the test?
>
> Because my production code parses this XML, so I want my test to do the
> same.

Sure, but why do you want the code that parses / transforms xml to objects
and the code that works with these objects *in one test*?
Why don't you have two test suites, one for reading / parsing and one for
working with these objects?

> > Just create a bunch of objects to play with and skip the XML part.
>
> And then one day, an XML driver is missing on my production code but my
> tests are still all happily green because they are using mock objects.

I do not say anything about mocks.

I do say, however, to test your XML driver independent of the code that
uses that XML driver's output. If your driver breaks, then obviously you
are missing a test in the former test suite, but not necessarily in the
later.

> Why is it so hard to understand that I want my tests to be as close to
> my production code as possible?!?

Don't know, maybe it's related to the way you try to explain?

Your tests don't seem to be unit tests to me, but end to end tests.
They seem to do too much.

Assume your data may also come from a database, not only from XML.
Do you then write all your test that deal with the objects *again*?
Or do you just test the objects in isolation and the the XML / DB readers
in isolation?

> > Please give an example where it does affect your test results
> > if the setup code runs for each test and where you still
> > claim that the tests are independent.
>
> How about the example I just gave?

A concrete example please. A test class with at least two test methods
that
a) are independent of each other
b) fail / pass if and only if setUp is / is not run
I have seen some pretty bad code but I still don't see how you want to
achieve that.

> Hint: imagine the XML file is several megabytes big. It's not that
> far fetched, really.

Hint: cut it down to simpler XML.
I cannot believe you have no duplication in terms of features in a several
megabytes file.
And if you do, why not use small chunks in each test? What about one test
per interesting feature of each XML entity?

I am curious how long your test methods are... more than 3 lines on
average?

Cheers,

Robert
